nodes.text: Cross-country economic growth (1960-1985) is determined by initial human capital, the initial level of per capita GDP, and policy/institutional factors such that higher initial human capital raises subsequent per capita growth while a higher initial per capita GDP (holding human capital fixed) lowers subsequent per capita growth; other factors (investment, fertility, government consumption, political instability, price distortions, regional effects) also affect growth
Initial human capital (proxied by 1960 school-enrollment rates) is positively related to per capita GDP growth (1960-1985)
Initial (1960) level of real per capita GDP is negatively related to subsequent per capita growth once initial human capital is held constant
Higher initial human capital is associated with lower fertility rates and higher physical investment ratios, mechanisms that reinforce higher growth

A larger share of government consumption in GDP is negatively associated with growth and private investment; public investment shows little positive effect on growth once total investment is controlled for
Political instability (revolutions, coups, assassinations) is negatively related to investment and growth, plausibly via adverse effects on property rights
Price distortions measured by deviations in purchasing-power-parity for investment goods (PPP investment deflator deviations) are negatively associated with growth and investment
Countries in sub-Saharan Africa and Latin America exhibit below-average growth that is not fully explained by the included variables, indicating remaining omitted factors or measurement shortcomings

Method: Cross-sectional OLS regressions (98 countries, mostly 1960-1985; dependent variables growth, fertility, investment), using proxies for human capital (SEC60, PRIM60), heteroskedasticity-consistent standard errors (White), weighted regressions and robustness checks

Evidence: Regression coefficient on GDP60 is -0.0075 (s.e. 0.0012) per $1000 (regression 1); a higher initial GDP lowers annual per capita growth by about 0.75 percentage points per $1,000 when human capital and other controls are included

Evidence: Coefficients on secondary and primary school-enrollment (SEC60, PRIM60) are positive and highly significant (t-values ~3.8 and 4.4), and joint F-test strongly rejects zero, indicating a robust positive partial effect of school enrollment on growth

Evidence: Partial associations show strong negative partial correlation between growth and GDP60 (partial corr -0.74) and strong positive partial correlation between growth and the human-capital index (partial corr 0.73), reconciling the zero simple correlation between growth and GDP60

Evidence: Fertility regressions (FERTNET) show school-enrollment variables are significantly negatively related to net fertility (holding GDP60), and population growth regressions align with these fertility results

Evidence: Investment regressions show private and total investment ratios are positively related to initial human capital and negatively related to GDP60 (partial relation), and residuals of growth and investment equations are positively correlated (~0.32-0.40)

Evidence: Government consumption share (gc/y) has a significant negative coefficient on growth (e.g., -0.12, s.e. 0.03) and a negative relation with private investment; public investment shares are insignificantly related to growth conditional on total investment

Evidence and residual findings: Political-instability variables (REV, ASSASS) negatively correlate with growth and investment; PPP investment-deflator deviation (PPIGODEV) magnitude negatively relates to growth; continent dummies for Africa and Latin America remain significantly negative for growth even after controls, and robustness checks indicate results persist under alternative dependent periods, weighting, and tests for measurement error
